text: Dog owners know the drill.
Dogs eat some really dumb things, including poisons.
Like This one.

Cocoa contains a molecule called
theobromine that’s very toxic to dogs.

Theobromine and caffeine.
Notice any similarities here?
It’s more than just looks too.

Like caffeine, theobromine blocks 
adenosine from reaching receptors in
our brains that regulate wakefulness.

In small doses, theobromine increases
heart rate, and the flow of oxygen
and nutrients to the brain.

But dogs don’t metabolize
theobromine very well.
So it’s effects last longer.

Bad news for a dog’s 
central nervous system.

It takes between 6 and 12 hours for the
symptoms of theobromine poisoning to set in.

Signs of theobromine poisoning:
High temperature, diarrhea, chocolate

wrappers, seizures, vomiting, rapid 
breathing, increased heart rate.

The LD50 is the amount of a substance that
will kill off half of a test population.
For dogs it’s 300mg per 1kg.
For people it’s 1000mg per 1kg.

Over 3X more (Which is why chocoholics
aren’t worried about it.)

Different kinds of chocolate have
different concentrations of theobromine.

Milk Chocolate: Up to 0.02% (60mg Per 1oz)
and Dark Chocolate: Up to 1.4% (400mg Per 1oz).

So for a 20kg (44lbs) dog to reach 
the LD50, it would require…

100 oz of milk chocolate (over 6 pounds)
15oz of bakers chocolate (almost 1 pound)
to reach the LD50.

But that’s the lethal dosage. Eating even a 
small amount can still make your dog sick.

The smaller the dog, the
higher the risk of poisoning.

If your dog eats some chocolate,
hydrogen peroxide can induce vomiting.
Call your vet for instructions first.

Theobromine has even harsher effects
on cats, but don’t worry too much.

Cats aren’t hunting for chocolate.
They can’t taste sweets.
That explains it.
Watch these other videos to learn things:

Why do dogs smell each other’s butts?
The chemistry of cats.
THANKS FOR WATCHING.
